info.game_comments: Clues featured (out of order) in the opening scene of the TV film Homeless to Harvard: The Liz Murray Story.

(1, 1).clue: In 1978 Chiang Kai-shek's son, Chiang Ching-kuo, was elected president of this island nation

(2, 1).clue: A violin doesn't have these dividing lines on its fingerboard as a guitar does

(3, 1).clue: In ancient rites, human blood was used to christen a ship; today it's usually this liquid

(4, 1).clue: The nation's oldest existing 3rd party, it was founded in 1869 to prevent the manufacture & sale of liquor

(5, 1).clue: "SCTV"'s spoof of this intellectual roundtable was called "Firing Squad"

(6, 1).clue: Mother Goose character who sat on a wall & had a great fall

(1, 2).clue: A Japanese military center from 1868 to 1945, this city is now home to Peace Memorial Park

(2, 2).clue: A lithophone is an old oriental percussion instrument made of this, but you wouldn't find it in a rock band

(3, 2).clue: Popular during both world wars, this "fortune-telling" board is now made by Parker Brothers

(4, 2).clue: In 1968 this American Independent Party candidate received almost 10 million votes & won 5 states

(5, 2).clue: In titles of TV series, this word has preceded heat, court & gallery

(1, 3).clue: China's Grand Canal connects these 2 rivers

(2, 3).clue: It has no historic connection with the Hebrews; its name may be an alteration of jaw

(3, 3).clue: This common gesture of friendship arose from the need to prove that you weren't carrying a weapon

(4, 3).clue: Norman Thomas was this party's presidential candidate in every election from 1928 to 1948

(5, 3).clue: This TV character's name was Zeb, but most of the other Waltons called him this

(6, 3).clue: 1940s style with tight cuffed trousers, wide lapels & heavily padded shoulders

(1, 4).clue: Singapore & Malaysia were formerly ruled by this European country

(2, 4).clue: A hi-hat is a foot-operated pair of these

(3, 4).clue: This fabulous fad of the 1950s still comes in a plastic egg-shaped container

(4, 4).clue: He was the last Federalist candidate to be elected president

(5, 4).clue: "Primetime Live" star of whom it was said, "If there were no television, he would go door-to-door"

(6, 4).clue: Mischievous imp that might wreck the machinery in a Moscow landmark

(1, 5).clue: The 2 countries whose shared border, set in 1945, roughly follows the 38th Parallel

(2, 5).clue: A glockenspiel sounds like these, "glocken" being the German word for them

(3, 5).clue: This practice originated in the fear that a new bride might bring bad luck into a house
(3, 5).correct response: Carrying the bride across the threshold

(4, 5).clue: Formed to oppose Andrew Jackson, this party's 1st program was Clay's "American System" favoring high tariffs

(5, 5).clue: At the end of "Book II" of this miniseries, Rudy Jordache was shot by Falconetti

(1, 1).clue: The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts overlooks this river

(2, 1).clue: Quechua, widely spoken in Peru & Ecuador, was the mother tongue of this ancient Indian nation

(3, 1).clue: This 1-celled protozoan gets its name from a Greek word meaning "change"

(4, 1).clue: The 1914 Welsh Church Act declared that this was no longer the official church of Wales

(5, 1).clue: King Olaf II is this country's patron saint

(6, 1).clue: This Italian got 1 of his 1st breaks when he replaced Clifton Webb in a dance act—how chic

(1, 2).clue: Type of theatrical make-up whose name is found in the title of an Anthony Newley musical

(2, 2).clue: Of all Semite languages, this one is spoken by the most people

(3, 2).clue: Because there are no blood vessels in this layer of skin, nutrition is supplied by a tissue fluid

(4, 2).clue: His name is the Greek translation of the Hebrew name "Joshua", which means "Jehovah is Salvation"

(5, 2).clue: His infant son, Fuad II, succeeded him briefly as king of Egypt after his abdication in 1952

(6, 2).clue: In 1989 this ballet star made his stage debut as an actor in "The King & I"—shall we dance?

(1, 3).clue: Tolstoy's "Tzar Fyodor Ivanovich" was the 1st play produced at this Russian theater in 1898

(2, 3).clue: The 1st written record of this language is a transcription of the Strasbourg Oaths of 842

(3, 3).clue: The opposite of ventral; this term refers to the back region of animals

(4, 3).clue: Martin Luther objected to the papal policy of selling these to remit penalty for sins

(5, 3).clue: "Good King" whose statue looks out on the square in Prague that's named for him

(6, 3).clue: He helped Hitler write "Mein Kampf" & later joined his cabinet

(1, 4).clue: This director died just hours before the opening of his last hit musical, "42nd Street"

(2, 4).clue: In this country, Serbo-Croatian is written in the Cyrillic alphabet & Croato-Serbian is written in the Roman alphabet

(3, 4).clue: It's the classification above species, but below family

(4, 4).clue: Specific term for someone who claims to be pope when there already is one

(5, 4).clue: King Gustav III of this country died after being shot at a masked ball in 1792

(6, 4).clue: This president fits the category because his middle name is Rudolph

(1, 5).clue: The characters in his play "Hay Fever" were inspired by actress Laurette Taylor & her family

(2, 5).clue: Standard Spanish originated in this ancient kingdom on the Iberian Peninsula

(3, 5).clue: The system of giving 2 scientific names to all organisms was devised by this Swedish naturalist

(4, 5).clue: Mohammed's flight from Mecca ended at this city, considered Islam's 2nd holiest

(5, 5).clue: The Oldenburg Dynasty founded by King Christian I ruled this country from 1448-1863

(6, 5).clue: This composer wrote "The Donkey Seranade" for the film version of one of his operettas

(0, 0).clue: He first appeared as the title character in the 1630 drama "The Seducer of Seville"
